CHANGES TO IN-PERSON LEARNING SCHEDULE: We have some significant upcoming changes in our phased-in return to school plan that we want to share with you.

Tacoma Public Schools plans to start Sept. 28 with:

• Preschoolers attending school in cohorts on a reduced schedule.
• Kindergarten students attending school four days per week—Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday.

Students in first and second grade will not attend school in person starting Sept. 28, as we previously planned. They will continue on the remote learning path for now.

Get more information here: https://bit.ly/33I1eqE

Today we had a derogatory and hateful email message sent from a student email account to large groups of district staff and student accounts. From there, some other students who received the message replied all or forwarded the message to others.

Within a few minutes of the first message being sent, our Technology Services Department changed the password to the original student’s account and began removing the offensive emails from the system.

To help prevent these incidents in the future, you can do two things:

- Please make sure students change the default password on their district-issued laptop.

- Do not reply or forward any offensive emails. Instead, report them to the Technology Services Help Desk.

Tacoma Public Schools is taking public comment regarding a potential intergovernmental transfer of the Gault Middle School campus to the Tacoma Housing Authority. Community engagement by the Tacoma Housing Authority will shape the ultimate use and improvement of the property. We want to know what you think about a proposal to rename Woodrow Wilson High School. The purpose of this survey is to collect a large sample of thoughts with the goal of presenting information to the Tacoma School Board in the fall of 2020. Ultimately, a name change would require a vote of the school board.

The idea of renaming the school came about when alumni and community members voiced concerns after press about Princeton University officials deciding to eliminate Woodrow Wilson's name from their campus. Alumni contacted the Tacoma School District superintendent and Wilson principal about the policy and process for renaming. The committee members, who will make a recommendation to the school board, include staff, students, parents, alumni, community members and a historian.

Every school year, part of the routine involves shifting teachers to match where students show up for the beginning of school. The COVID-19 pandemic means that this upcoming school year will see teachers shifting assignments more than ever before.

Some of our educators have informed us of underlying health conditions that mean we need to find critical instructional roles that keep them from the classroom when in-person instruction resumes.

And thousands of our students have chosen to enroll in Tacoma Online—a fully online learning experience.

All of this means that many of our teachers will shift to new schools, new grade levels, new subject matter. Some will shift from classroom instruction to supporting students enrolled in Tacoma Online.

We ask for your patience as we make these changes to match our students’ needs and the restrictions from the pandemic.

This video shows you what happens in a normal year.

“To know that I have this much support from the community, it just makes me feel like—I have people behind me who are in this work with me, who believe that my parents are the most amazing parents in Tacoma and want to support that,” said Taylor.

Distribution plans are still in the works and will be shared with Manitou Park Elementary families in the next few days.

Thank you to Tacoma Costco, Microsoft, Tacoma Public Schools Partnership Office, families, teachers, and every community member who donated. It will help our students start strong.

The Tacoma School Board approved a new grading policy for elementary, middle and high school students, based on options provided by the Office of Superintendent of Public Instruction. The policy was built on the desire to do no harm to students, and to give every student the chance to improve their standing.

Elementary: Report cards for kindergarten through fifth-grade students at the end of this school year will show one of three marks:

Level 2: Approaching end of year standard

Level 3: Meeting end of year standard, or

Level 4: Exceeding end of year standard

Middle and high school: For the second semester of the school year, a student will receive a traditional letter grade ranging from A to C.

Students will not receive failing grades.

Emily Coates has a sense about when someone needs help. In her neighborhood, people know her as the “Hilltop mama,” a person who’s going to notice when things are going well with families in the area, and when they’re not.

She’s been known to leave hot meals and diapers on her porch for neighbors to grab as they need them. When families don’t have transportation, she’ll pick up a box of donated supplies and make sure they’re delivered.

“There’s a lot of us out here just being the mamas to everyone,” Coates said. “In the summer, we make sure that kids are fed. In the winter, we make sure they have coats and shoes. Now - with everything people are going through - is just an extension of that. It’s just what you do. We’re ‘momming’ together.”

“Emily serves the entire Hilltop neighborhood,” said Bryant Montessori Family Liaison Jenna Buswell. “She’s always on patrol. People tell her what they need and she makes it happen, making sure kids are safe and well. She’s an emotional bright light.”

Thank you, Emily, for looking out for Tacoma’s kids. We appreciate you.
#WeGotThisTacoma

GREAT IDEA: In Discovery Channel’s recognition of Earth Day, two IDEA students explain the scientific research they’re doing to ultimately improve the environment.

Stephanos Mavrommatis and Kedrick Bennett, both part of a long-term grant that IDEA applied for with the City of Tacoma, are studying the impact of permeable pavement on stormwater.

The school repaved its entire parking lot with five different mixtures of permeable pavement in January 2019, complete with underwater plumbing and advanced sensors that allow IDEA students and scientists from Washington State University to study the impact permeable pavement has on filtering out groundwater pollutants over three years.

Check out our students sharing some of their work in Chapter 4: Water. Stephanos and Kedrick are part of the first senior class from this innovative school, a collaborative creative environment centered around industrial design, engineering and the arts.

Thank you to the dozen volunteers of Raising Girls. Each volunteer delivers hygiene products to Tacoma students in need. They do what they have to do to get students the supplies they need to feel clean and comfortable.

In 2019, Raising Girls provided 1,200 hygiene supply bags to our students. Only four months into 2020, they’ve already provided 2,000. The need is real, and it’s significant at our middle and high schools.

Lincoln High School Principal Pat Erwin can attest to that, and he’s grateful for the support Raising Girls provides his students – both female and male.

“The thing that I really appreciate during the COVID-19 crisis is that everyone who has a tendency to care is caring even more,” Erwin said. “But I appreciate organizations that exist outside times of crisis, too. Kids don’t have a choice in a lot of the things that affect them, and we need to be able to serve them no matter what.”

YOU ARE NOT ALONE. Yesterday, when Ms. Carrick, a 2nd/3rd grade teacher at Bryant, heard we would not return to the classroom this year—she felt the weight of those words. We all did with frustrations, sadness and tears.

“One of the hardest parts of this experience so far has been missing the shared space and community that my students and I have built in our classroom together. I have had the privilege of being able to build and grow a community this year with some of the most incredible, creative, hilarious, empathetic students I have ever met. I miss getting to witness their discoveries, vulnerabilities, mistakes, realizations and laughter in real time.

I hope that students and families take away that all of the things they're feeling are okay, and also how much all of us in education who can't be with them are thinking about them and want to support them however we can. None of us are alone in this.”

Her message is shared by us all. We miss you and we’ll figure this out—together.

#WeGotThisTacoma.

Stories like this serve as examples that we are rising to the occasion together, seeking out and helping meet our community’s basic needs. #WeGotThisTacoma

Breathe: For students and families, the sudden closure of schools may cause emotional stress. Our Whole Child lessons website has resources and lessons to help keep students and families safe, healthy, challenged, engaged and supported. We will continue to add information and resources to this site often.

Our first topic is stress management. Here’s a quick mindfulness exercise. You can do this when you need to calm your mind or body.

Get into a comfortable position and close your eyes. Focus on listening to your breathing. Feel the air entering through your nose, filling up your lungs and blowing out of your mouth.

Inhale slowly through your nose. Place your fingers gently on your ears to block out sounds. Breathe out through your mouth, saying “buzzzzzzzzzzz” for as long as you can. Repeat.

Try a different sound such as “hummmmmmm” or “ohhhhhhhhh”.
Repeat the bumble bee breathing until your body is calm and relaxed.

For Reese Holiday-Tate, Jennie Reed Elementary Title I para-educator, relationships are the key.

For Classified Employees Week, we asked some of our rock star staff what they love about their jobs. One common theme emerged: their commitment to student growth.

It doesn’t matter if Reese is helping students in the lunchroom, on the playground or in the classroom, she believes, “My success goes back to relationships with my students. You gotta have that relationship with students in order for them to grow. And you’ll grow too. Your heart is big, and you want the best for them. You want them to succeed, you want them to feel loved. And that’s how Jennie Reed is, it’s not just me. As a para, I do it all. I love to build great relationships. The kids are always coming up to me, calling out my name, giving me a hug. I love it.”

Thank you, Reese and all classified employees at Tacoma Public Schools. Your dedication and support make a tremendous difference to our students, families, and community.

Happy Lunar New Year! The Year of the Rat! Tacoma Public Schools assisted our community partner, Asia Pacific Cultural Center in hosting the 22nd Annual Lunar New Year event Feb. 8 in the Tacoma Dome Exhibition Hall.

Cultures across Asia and the globe celebrate Lunar New Year; however, Vietnam was this year’s event host country. Lunar New Year or Tết Nguyên Đán, is the most important national celebration in the Vietnamese culture. The event featured live performances from 15 Asia Pacific cultures: Vietnam, Korea, Cambodia, Hawaii, Japan, Tonga/Fiji, Philippines, China, Guan, Okinawa, Indonesia, India, Taiwan, Laos and Samoa.

Dignitaries from the local, county and state government agencies as well as educational, civics and community leaders attended the event. Two surprise awards were given during the event. TPS Deputy Superintendent Dr. Joshua Garcia received a Community Service Award. And TPS Executive Director for English Language Learners & Global Education Programs, Dr. Minh-Anh Hodge, received the Unsung Hero Award.

Life is full of surprises, and a traumatic event such as an unexpected death of a student or staff member can be overwhelming and drastically shift a learning environment. Our Crisis Response Team establishes a system of supports for students and school staff when they need it the most.

Jasmyne Walton, Wainwright Intermediate
“Building relationships is the cornerstone of my role as a school counselor. It's an honor and privilege to work with students, families, and staff; especially during a time of high need. When students are at their most vulnerable moments they trust me to listen with empathy, genuine concern, respect, and compassion. I can do so because I value them and who they are. Our students are important to me. I know what I say or do can resound with them for the rest of their lives, whether I remember that exact moment or not. I put my all into building relationships with students because they are worth it. Our students are why I became a school counselor. They are why I return day after day, ready for whatever the day may bring.”

#NSCW2020

The shift from elementary to middle school, and from middle to high school can bring not only new learning challenges but new environments and social pressures. Our Tacoma team is dedicated to helping students (and parents) set the stage for success at every level.

Ravi Jaskar, Stewart Middle School
“I have had the pleasure of working as a School Counselor in Tacoma Public Schools for the past 13 years, 11 of which have been at Stewart Middle School. Students in middle school make a huge amount of growth and begin making connections to what they want to be and where they want to go. As a middle school counselor, I work to provide opportunities for students to discover and explore their interests. My favorite event of the year is our Annual College and Career Week in March, which gives students a chance to see future possibilities. Helping students make the transition from elementary to being high school ready is my passion. “
